This programme is designed to help you understand that the number system we use today- the Hindu-Arabic numerals isn\'t natural but came into scene after a series of evolution in our number system.

The development of numbers began as people counted their belongings. the peoples of the world used various kings of ways to count their possessions. for instance, if a man wanted to keep the records of the number of goats and sheep he had. if he had 17 goats and 21 sheep, he would have to pick up 17 stones or sticks to represent the number of goats he had 21 stones or stickes to represent the number of sheep he had.

Overtime, since stones are circular in shape and stickes-strokes like, people developed the ability of using circular or stroke like inscription on walla or large stones to represent numbers. so, if a farmer had 17 goats he either drew 17 circular shapes or 17 strokes to represent the number of goats he had as shown below /n 00000000000000000 /n OR /////////////////

off all the stroke-like manner of representating numbers by different people of the world, the tally system became the first notable, primitive and stroke-like system of representing numbers that drew the attention of early scholar though not ascribed to any nation

The tally system is a primitive number system that was developed in the course of taking records of an individual\'s or team\'s score or amount gained in an event which could be a sport, game, vote, trade e.t.c in this system, stroke are used and the number of strokes are used and the number of strokes made are updated to always tally (agree) with the present score of the individual or team in such a way that the intermediate records are not erased.
